method.name: Apriori

reference.ref: R. Srikant and R. Agrawal. Mining quantitative association rules in large relational tables. In ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data, pages 1–12, Montreal, Quebec, Canada (1996).
C. Borgelt. Efficient implementations of Apriori and Eclat. In Workshop on Frequent Itemset Mining Implementations, volume 90, pages 280–296. CEUR Workshop Proc., Florida, USA (2003).

generalDescription.type: Association Rules Mining by means of Classical Algorithms
generalDescription.objective: Apriori is the first successful algorithm used for mining quantitative association rules. We have provided a fast implementation of this algorithm by employing prefix trees for counting the support of frequent itemsets.
generalDescription.howWork: The main aim of Apriori is to explore the search space by means of the downward closure property. The latter states that any subset of a frequent itemset must also be frequent. As a consequence, it generates candidates for the current iteration by means of frequent itemsets collected from the previous iteration. Then, it enumerates all the subsets for each transaction and increments the support of candidates which match them. Finally, those having a user-specified minimum support are marked as frequent for the next iteration. This process is repeated until all frequent itemsets have been found. Therefore, Apriori follows a breadth-first strategy to generate candidates. The algorithm usually ends when the maximum size of frequent itemsets is reached. This size is always fixed to the total number of attributes of the given database. However, the process may terminate earlier if there are no new discovered frequent itemsets at the end of an iteration.

parameterSpec.param: Number of Partitions for Numeric Attributes: the number of uniform partitions used for splitting numerical domains.
Minimum Support: the minimum support to be fullfilled by the mined association rules.
Minimum Confidence: the minimum confidence to be fullfilled by the mined association rules.

method.example:
Problem type: Association Rules Method: Apriori Dataset: weather Parameters: default values
After the execution of RunKeel.jar we can see XML representations of the mined association rules along with the values concerning the measures of interest, respectively, in:
"results/Asso-Apriori.weather/result0.tra"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rules> <rule id="0"> <antecedents> <attribute name="outlook" value="sunny"/> <attribute name="temperature" value="hot"/> </antecedents> <consequents> <attribute name="humidity" value="high"/> </consequents> </rule> ... ... ... ... <rule id="51"> <antecedents> <attribute name="humidity" value="normal"/> </antecedents> <consequents> <attribute name="play" value="yes"/> </consequents> </rule> </rules>
"results/Asso-Apriori.weather/result0.tst"
